header.title: Der Schamane und der Magier: Reisen zwischen den Welten
header.category: Western Esotericism, Shamanism, Occultism, Depth Psychology

central_thesis: This book explores the profound parallels between traditional shamanism and Western occult magic, demonstrating how both traditions utilize altered states of consciousness (trance, visions) for spiritual journeys, self-transformation, and accessing hidden knowledge. It argues that modern depth psychology offers analogous frameworks for understanding individual initiation, and emphasizes the enduring relevance of mythical thought in contemporary society, advocating for its re-integration to access deeper aspects of consciousness.

structure_content.summary: Harner introduces Drury's work, highlighting its significance in drawing connections between Carlos Castaneda's shamanism, Western magic, and occultism. He commends Drury's unique insight, possibly derived from practical experience, that modern Western occult trance states and visions bear striking resemblances to classical shamanism.

Drury outlines the purpose of the book: to examine the re-emerging interest in the shamanic figure, acknowledging its influence from Carlos Castaneda's popular works. He notes the cross-cultural universality of shamanic themes (magical journey, cosmic connection) and states his dual perspective as an anthropologist and a practitioner of Western esoteric traditions. The chapter sets the stage for demonstrating how mythical thinking remains vital in the modern world.

This chapter defines the shaman as a master of trance, capable of soul-journeys to upper and lower cosmic realms to interact with spiritual beings. It provides examples from Jivaro (using natema hallucinogen for arutam wakan and jaguar visions), Evenki (with their world tree cosmology, animal helper spirits, and the shaman's drum as a vehicle), and Mazateca (employing psilocybin and incorporating Christian elements into their healing practices). A central theme discussed is the shamanic initiation process involving symbolic dismemberment and rebirth.

Drury differentiates shamanic trance from pathological states like epilepsy, emphasizing the shaman's conscious control and memory of the experience. Various trance induction techniques are described, including sensory deprivation, sleep deprivation, fasting, breath exercises, and hallucinogens. The chapter asserts that altered states of consciousness are universal but culturally molded, and highlights the shaman's ability to navigate these states to gain knowledge and facilitate healing, exemplified by the Iglulik Eskimo shaman's journey to the Sea Goddess Sedna.

This section draws parallels between the magical universe of modern occultists, particularly the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn, and classical shamanism. It differentiates between ritual invocation (identifying with deities like Osiris, Ra, Zeus) and controlled out-of-body 'pathworkings' on the Tree of Life. Key ritual components are discussed: specific attire symbolizing the journey, the magical altar and weapons (sword, chalice, staff, pentacle) representing elemental forces and Sephiroth, and the use of divine names and mantras for invoking power and concentration.

The practical methods for inducing trance in Western occultism are detailed, often referred to as astral projection or pathworking. These involve mental relaxation, intellectual focus, and sensory deprivation, channeling attention inward. Examples from Golden Dawn practitioners like J. W. Brodie Innes describe visualizing symbols and entering visionary landscapes. The Tree of Life is presented as a cosmological map for inner journeys. The 'Middle Pillar' exercise for circulating energy and various techniques using Tarot paths, Tattvas (Hindu elemental symbols), and Enochian squares as visual and conceptual frameworks for trance experiences are explained.

structure_content.chapter_title: 5 Neue Stromungen: Vom Wiederaufstieg des Atavistischen zum Inneren Licht
structure_content.summary: This chapter explores post-Golden Dawn developments in magic, focusing on active imagination techniques. Austin Osman Spare's 'Atavistic Resurgence' system is presented, where sigils are used to evoke primal, ancestral forms and past incarnations from the unconscious, often blurring the lines between waking and visionary reality. Edwin Steinbrecher's 'Guide Meditation' uses Tarot archetypes and inner guides for self-exploration and therapeutic insight. Dion Fortune's 'Fraternity of the Inner Light' emphasizes the feminine principle (Isis) and employs guided meditations like 'Highways of the Mind' for astral travel and spiritual transformation, showing evolution in modern magical practice.

Drury reiterates the book's core argument: the comparative study of shamanism and Western magic highlights the enduring need for mythical thinking in modern, scientifically dominated society. He posits that suppressing mythical thought leads to spiritual impoverishment and that humanity requires access to the numinous and intuitive visionary experiences. Both traditions offer methods for transforming the mundane and achieving cosmic rebirth.

structure_content.chapter_title: Anhang A: Schamanismus, Magie und die Erforschung des Bewuötseins
structure_content.summary: This appendix delves into the psychological and neuroscientific underpinnings of altered states of consciousness in shamanism and magic. It discusses research on brain hemispheres, EEG patterns (Alpha, Theta waves), and sensory deprivation. It covers C.G. Jung's archetypes and collective unconscious, linking them to mythical encounters. Psychotherapeutic techniques like active imagination (Desoille, Caslant, Leuner) are compared to magical journeys. The importance of cultural belief systems in shaping visionary experiences (Lilly, Levi-Strauss) and the concept of lucid dreams are also explored.

structure_content.chapter_title: Anhang B: Die wichtigsten mythologischen Entsprechungen in der westlichen Magie
structure_content.summary: This appendix provides a table of correspondences between Kabbalistic Sephiroth and various Greek, Roman, and Egyptian deities, illustrating the syncretic nature of Western magic and its integration of diverse mythological systems. It serves as a technical reference for practitioners to understand the symbolic framework underlying magical operations.

This section lists the academic and source references used throughout the book, including works by Mircea Eliade, Michael Harner, C. Blacker, A.P. Elkin, G. Reichel-Dolmatoff, A. Crowley, D. Fortune, C.G. Jung, S. Grof, and various specialized texts on hallucinogens and shamanism.

key_concepts.definition: A practice involving a practitioner (shaman) who enters altered states of consciousness (trance) to interact with the spirit world for healing, divination, or guidance, often characterized by soul-journeys to upper or lower cosmic realms and mastery over spirits.

A practical system aiming for spiritual transformation and the acquisition of knowledge/power through rituals, ceremonial practices, and the manipulation of symbols. It often involves 'pathworking' through cosmological maps like the Tree of Life and conscious interaction with archetypal entities.

A controlled, non-pathological state of altered awareness, deliberately induced by various techniques, allowing the practitioner (shaman or magician) to shift perception from the mundane to an inner, visionary reality, retaining memory and control over the experience.

A central Kabbalistic diagram representing the cosmos, divine emanations (Sephiroth), and paths of consciousness. In Western magic, it serves as a map for inner journeys, self-transformation, and understanding the hierarchical structure of the universe and psyche.

Universal, primordial patterns and images (Jungian concept) residing in the collective unconscious, which manifest in dreams, visions, and myths. In shamanism and magic, these often appear as deities, spirits, or symbolic figures encountered during altered states.

A psychotherapeutic technique, also employed in magic, involving conscious engagement with inner images, fantasies, or symbols to explore the unconscious, facilitate dialogue with internal figures, and integrate psychic contents.

A technique to reduce external sensory input (e.g., darkness, silence, floating) to induce altered states of consciousness, facilitating inward focus and the emergence of inner visions and perceptions.

Five elemental symbols (Tejas-Fire, Apas-Water, Vayu-Air, Prithivi-Earth, Akasha-Spirit) from Hindu mythology, used in Western magic, particularly in the Golden Dawn, as visual stimuli to induce trance states and evoke elemental visions.

A complex magical system based on the purported angelic communications received by John Dee and Edward Kelley. It involves specific 'Enochian squares' and letters used for ritual invocation and triggering visions during trance, often for cosmic exploration.

A central theme in both shamanic and magical traditions, signifying a profound spiritual transformation often preceded by symbolic death, dismemberment, or a crisis experience, leading to enhanced powers, renewed identity, and deeper cosmic connection.

Spiritual entities, often in animal or human-like forms, that assist the shaman or magician during their journeys in altered states, providing guidance, protection, and aid in magical operations or healing.

practical_system.description: The book analyzes practical systems for inducing altered states of consciousness and undertaking spiritual journeys. It details methods from traditional shamanism (e.g., drumming, hallucinogens for soul flight) and Western occult magic (e.g., Golden Dawn rituals, pathworking on the Tree of Life, Enochian magic, Austin Osman Spare's sigil work, and guided meditations). The focus is on the operative side: how these techniques facilitate self-transformation, interaction with archetypes and spirits, and access to hidden knowledge.
tools: Shaman's Drum (for inducing rhythmic trance and as a symbolic vehicle)
Spear (shamanic tool, symbolizing power or direction)
Hallucinogenic plants and substances (e.g., natema, psilocybin mushrooms, Datura, Peyote, Yage, Amanita muscaria)
Ritual attire or costume (for symbolic identification and entering sacred space)
Magical Altar (a focal point for ritual, symbolizing the magical will or cosmic structure)
Magical Circle (for protection and containment of energies, defining sacred space)
Magical Weapons (e.g., Sword for control/strength, Chalice for reception/water, Staff for will/air, Pentacle/Coin for manifestation/earth, each associated with elements and Sephiroth)
Divine names, mantras, and words of power (for invocation, protection, and directing magical will)
Incense and perfumes (to create appropriate atmospheric correspondences for deities/spirits)
Tarot cards (especially the Greater Arcana, used as archetypal maps for pathworking and meditation)
Tattvas cards or symbols (visual aids for elemental meditations)
Enochian squares/tables (for Enochian magic and vision scrying)
Crystals (for scrying and as receptacles for magical energy)
Wachstafeln (wax tablets) and Almadele (for Enochian magic records and scrying)
rituals: Shamanic Trance Induction (e.g., rhythmic drumming, chanting, sensory deprivation, fasting, use of hallucinogenic plants like natema or psilocybin)
Symbolic Dismemberment and Rebirth (a central shamanic initiation process for acquiring power and a new identity)
Golden Dawn Ceremonial Magic (involving ritual invocation of deities, use of divine names and words of power for self-identification with divine forms, often performed within a magical circle)
Pathworking on the Tree of Life (mental journeys through the Sephiroth and connecting paths, visualizing and interacting with specific archetypal energies and symbols)
Middle Pillar Exercise (a Kabbalistic meditation for circulating divine energy through the subtle body, aligning with the Sephiroth)
Tattvavision (meditation on Hindu elemental symbols to evoke corresponding elemental visions and energies)
Enochian Trance (visualization of Enochian squares and ascension through 'Aethyrs' to receive angelic communications)
Austin Osman Spare's Atavistic Resurgence (creation and charging of sigils to evoke primal, atavistic forces and past incarnations from the unconscious, often through sexual gnosis)
Guide Meditation (using inner guides or Tarot archetypes to navigate inner landscapes for therapeutic insight and self-discovery, as developed by Edwin Steinbrecher)

Inner Light 'Highways of the Mind' Meditations (guided elemental journeys and encounters with archetypes like the Great Mother, for astral travel and spiritual transformation, as practiced by Dolores Ashcroft-Nowicki and the Servants of the Light)

relevant_quotes.text: Der Schamane ist der Spezialist einer Trance, in der seine Seele den Korper zu Himmel- und Unterweltfahrten verlaöt.

Nevill Drury zeigt, vielleicht deutlicher als die meisten vor ihm, daö in der Trance und den Visionen der modernen westlichen okkulten Magie zuweilen Aspekte auftreten, die denen des klassischen Schamanismus erstaunlich ahneln.

Ein wichtiges Kennzeichen des Schamanen ist seine Fahigkeit, in der Trance die Bewuötseinsebene zu verschieben. Sein normales Bewuötsein ist blockiert, und in seinem Unbewuöten tauchen Szenen aus der Mythologie und Religion seines Volkes auf.

Der Okkultist bewegt sich nicht nur in einem geordneten, hierarchischen Universum, sondern bezieht sich vor allem auf den Baum des Lebens, die Weltachse, welche die Welt der Gottheit mit der des Menschen verbindet.
Die Wirkung war gewaltig: »Er spurte fast sofort eine Reaktion im Innern. Eine ungeheure Energie wallte auf und fegte durch seinen Korper.

Die groöen Inhalte, die dem Schamanismus und der westlichen Magie gemeinsam sind, wurden hier also nicht bloö aus akademischem Interesse zusammengebracht, sondern sollen zeigen, daö auch in der modernen Welt unserer Stadte der mythische Weg zum menschlichen Bewuötsein neben der angewandten Naturwissenschaft eine wesentliche Rolle spielt.

critical_analysis.relevance: The book is highly relevant for understanding the commonalities and underlying psychological mechanisms of diverse spiritual traditions, bridging ancient shamanic practices with Western occult magic and modern depth psychology. It provides a robust argument for the continued necessity of mythical thought and symbolic experience in a rationalistic world, offering a framework for validating and integrating subjective visionary experiences.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience includes general readers interested in comparative religion, shamanism, magic, and occultism, as well as practitioners seeking deeper theoretical and practical insights into their chosen path. Academics in anthropology, psychology, and religious studies will find its interdisciplinary approach to altered states of consciousness and mythologies particularly valuable.
